title: How should Capitalize in LLC? how important is to give amount in capitalization when LLC has Two partner?
question: how important is to give amount in capitalization when LLC has Two partner?
answers:
I agree with Attorney Ashouri.

It is critical - for legal and accounting purposes - to specify each member's capital contribution in the Operating Agreement. (As concerns accounting, please see the post at the link below.)

It is very important. Failure to properly put money into the business can create all sorts of issues down the road. Piercing the entity by creditors, even the IRS. Plus, this helps establish the relationships of the partners. Often times, disputes occur and if a partner has not put money into the LLC it can create a big disadvantage for the member not contributing. It is called lack of consideration. You also might run into an income tax issue if the member shares are not actually purchased. I have seen many LLC capitalized for anywhere from $2,500-$10,000.

http://taxbizlawyer.com/why-incorporate-a-business.htm

The above is not legal advice. It is an illustration of options that can be used in certain situations. I have not examined all of your facts, if I did I might provide a different response.

You received valuable advice from my able colleagues above. The only thing I want to add is that it is very important that you adequately capitalize the LLC at its inception. People form an entity normally for tax reasons and to protect their personal assets from the company's creditors. Unfortunately, under the doctrine of "piercing the corporate veil" the courts can and do hold the shareholders or members personally liable for the debts of the business under certain circumstances. The issue of capitalization at the inception of an entity comes under scrutiny and plays an important role in the decision whether to pierce the corporate veil or not.

I agree with my colleagues. I add that I really doubt you will file the correct forms with the Commissioner of Corportions or otherwise properly issue your securities (membership insterests).

To offer something of value: don't forget to prepare a "buy-sell" agreement. There is no public market for your shares. If one of you dies, becomes permanently disabled, or just wants to get out, there is no way to compel the LLC or your "partner" to buy you out. Further, if you don't agree on a formula (not a number but a way of arriving at a number in the future) now, it just won't happen when the time comes.

Develop a team of professionals who will get to know you from the beginning of your business.
The capitalization amounts must be identified in the operating agreement. If capitalized then there is an amount. Not sure if follow your question clearly. Also should run by your CPA.
